Even at the heart of the 2008 crisis, we had only once a gap greater than 0.9 and it was when the kind of exponential had already well grown (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DRCRELEXFACBS). So I think it's rather unlikely that it be the case between Q1 and Q2 2021.

"After a slight deterioration at the end of 2020, commercial and multifamily mortgage performance improved for the second straight month in February, bringing delinquency rates down to the lowest level since April 2020" 
"Lodging and retail property loans continue to show the greatest stress, but the shares of outstanding loan balances that are delinquent have fallen from their peak levels by 25% and 28%, respectively. Across all property types, the share of outstanding balances becoming newly delinquent is also the lowest since the onset of the pandemic, and less than one-quarter of the level from April 2020."
https://www.mba.org/2021-press-releases/march/commercial-and-multifamily-mortgage-delinquency-rates-continue-to-vary-by-property-types-and-capital-sources

Major banks have been releasing their first quarter 2021 financials over the past week.  All are reporting a decline in delinquency rates from fourth quarter 2020.  Most the reports point out that they believe the slight rise in the second half of 2020 was the result of the pandemic, while the increase in the fourth quarter 2020 is a seasonal occurrence.  The delinquency rate remains close to historic lows.  Updating forecast to zero out "More than 4.00% but less than 6.00%" and reallocating 2% to "Between 2.00% and 4.00%, inclusive."  Maintaining 7% in "Between 2.00% and 4.00%, inclusive" to account for unforeseen issues, however, the federal and state governments continue to provide stimulus to businesses decreasing the possibility of an increased delinquency rate.

Very low.  Since the Great Recession recovery delinquency rates for commercial real estate loans have been below 2%.  With all of the federal and state stimulus money directed to businesses, the first of those funds are generally going to paying mortgages and loans.  Leave room for the unknowns (i.e. some unknown economic shock) in the short term.
People have gotten use to forgoing many services during the shutdown. Small enterprises will not fully recuperate thereby shutting down.
Caronna impact on commercial has been less and retail especially, is recovering better than I originally expected.  Fingers crossed!
Loan modification, The American Rescue Plan, along with funding SBA targeted PPP loans with correct the trajectory seen during Q4 2020.
Upping forecast on low wend Q1 not yet out but feels right

My thought exercise in my previous forecast and the evidence of past history (including a stable and predictable decreasing trend) and the sensible cause and effects of the COVID stimulus gives me strong reason to think it will not be over 2.00. The exact value I am not sure but maybe my previous forecast may help to answer which method is closest pending the outcome to this question. It may surely be close to the value of 2.00. I have found that the overall trend of delinquency rate has gone down over the decades, with the most recent anomaly being around the financial crisis of 2008. In this case, I found that the home price index in the U.S. dropped while delinquency rates skyrocketed way above the mean, then petered off when the delinquency rates started falling from its peak around 2009. Assuming they are correlated somehow, maybe even indirectly causing each other, I see that the home price index in the past year or two has not dropped but is in fact increasing. With this logic, we should see delinquency rates remaining stable or decreasing. Again, this is a hypothesis I would want to see play out. How I can see my forecast to be wrong is that the upward trend is more free to "go crazy" because we have already seen a rise in the last year. There has been an instance the rise comes back down before it could go out of hand, but we cannot rule out a surge. I can see my forecast going wrong if this trend exponentially increases. The thinking is that it will be above 1 and below 2, but that's very little wiggle room and UP is the favorite versus down. Misc.: I do not have any background in economics or financial stuff nor do I have any particular interest in them.

I think I was overweighting the chance of a surge in delinquencies from borrowers or lenders deciding they don't want to undergo a reporting-exempt TDR all of a sudden. There's a lot of support in the recent stimulus for the hotels and restaurants that could be used to at least partially pay rents, and if a lender does want to evict a tenant they can simply allow the lease (or restructured lease) to lapse in the cases where there are potential future tenants clamoring for commercial space. The historic trend is pretty clear, and the argument for deviation from it is weaker than I was previously believed.
Vaccination plan is going fast and economic projections for United States are strong (according to IMF). It was a hard hit but with fast recovery (the most probable scenario).

First Question to be asked: are there any comparables or base rates we can look for? How far is 2008 / 2009 comparable - since this was a pure real estate crisis / financial crisis in the first place and not an pandemic? I believe a comparison is helpful but only in some respects: 2008 / 09 were mainly consumers in the residential sector - so commercial real estate was less hit nevertheless the rates jumped above 8.6 at the peak. So theoretically it should  be possible that this time since office, retail, hotel and restaurants are even more severlly hit that we see similar new height.  On the other hand  this time politicians and the FED acted even quicker and more generous but how much this will help real businesses is the crucial question. I strongly believe that rates will pass 4.00 % easily but more in the form of a backlog or as Jeremy Grantham said a slow motion train wreck that slowly but surely shows its effect.  Liquidity crunch and everything that hinges indirectly on it like delinquincy rates are like a train crash . So my assesment weighing all the counteracting forces is, that we will see similar peaks but the time horizont in this question is too short to show the real effects until it works itself fully through the system, Next update in around 2 - 3 weeks when Fred data for Q1 are released and since in 2008 / 09 these effects are slow but sure adjustment in one direction or the other are made.

Very interesting question, before researching this I’d assumed that delinquencies would be super high, at least 2008 levels. Looking at the FRED plot though it’s been climbing by only 0.1-0.2 per quarter for the past several quarters. That puts the outside rate at almost definitely below 2%, high end growth by historic standards would put the rate at about 1.6%, and low end around 1.4%.  Going by news in the CRE world it seems like that a spike didn’t happen is because most of the loans that would’ve gone delinquent, mostly in the hospitality sector, we restructured rather than allowing the loan recipient to go into delinquency. This was done for COVID but not 2008 because of a section of the CARES act that allows for loans that would normally be considered troubled debt restructurings to be restructured without the reporting requirements and likely associated hit to the lender’s credit rating. The idea seems to be to incentivize banks to work out new agreements with tenants, helping tenants avoid delinquency being on their credit history, and letting banks not report large chunks of their loans as impaired and having their balance sheets look worse to the outside world.  If that’s the main reason that delinquency has been so low, it probably won’t be changing any time soon. The clause of the CARES act that allows for different treatment of TDRs under GAAP was renewed in the December 2020 stimulus through 2022 or 60 days after the end of the national emergency (https://www.natlawreview.com/article/federal-covid-relief-bill-passed-congress-december-2020) . The same incentives remain for both lenders and recipients to avoid delinquency, and the same provisions remain in place to allow them to avoid it.  I reserve some probability for a sharp increase though. A lot of would-be-TDRs were probably done at the beginning of the pandemic with a one year term for the agreement which would need to be updated soon. Most people at the beginning of the pandemic were expecting lockdowns to last a few months tops, and now that it’s become clear that the effects will be much larger and long-lasting than was expected when the first round of would-be-TDRs were done. This may mean that some tenants or lenders will decide that it’s better to just eat the loss from a bad loan, rather than continue paying even at a reduced rate since business won’t be coming back, which will lead to some going into delinquency. I’m not sure what the agreements actually look like or in what state many of the tenants are in (which was kind of the point of the provision), so it’s hard to say how likely this type of scenario actually is. It’s also hard to say if delinquency will be a common choice, since I’m not sure how often it will be in anybody’s best interest given the TDR options on the table, as well as pandemic relief programs that can be used to help tenants meet their loan payments.   Even in a bad scenario, the sharpest growth from 2008 was about 0.75 per quarter, and we’d need at least one quarter with growth on that level to have a shot at going over 2%, so I don’t assign it a huge weight. Most likely, present trends will continue.

Looking at this question again. Q4 2019 was a 0.68% delinquency rate.
Q1 2020 was a 21% increase on the 0.68% = 0.82
Q2 2020 was a 12% increase (over Q1 2020) = 0.92
Q3 2020 was a 10% increase (over Q2) = 1.01
Q4 2020 was a 15% increase (over Q3) = 1.16 If Q1 2021 increases by 15% it will be 1.33
If Q2 2021 increases by 15% it will be 1.53 In order to tick above 2.00, Q1 and Q2 will need to increase by 32% (1.16 x 1.32 = 1.5312 x 1.32 = 2.02) When we entered the 2008 recession the delinquency rate was 3.50. I just don't see a 32% increase for two consecutive quarters happening. I'm hedging a bit that people know something I don't, but the crowd is estimating between 2 and 4% which strikes me as very difficult to achieve given the 2 rounds of PPP and the recent stimulus funding which includes additional protection: https://www.inquirer.com/business/small-business/stimulus-ppp-loan-sba-debt-savings-restaurants-hotels-20210105.html Crowd, are we looking at the same data source (FRED)?

n the second quarter of 2020, under the effects of the coronavirus crisis, the mortgage delinquency rate in the United States spiked at 8.22 percent, just one percent down from its peak of 9.3 percent during the subprime mortgage crisis of 2007-2010. Following the drastic increase directly after the outbreak of the pandemic, delinquency rates started gradually declining in the second half of 2020.

Q4 is 1.16. Increase the past 4 qtrs has been +.14, +.10, +.09, +.15. A similar rate of increase would result in a range of 1.25-1.31%. The max increase in 1 qtr was during the 2008 financial crisis, +1.26, resulting in a ceiling of 2.42. 
The difference between now and 2008 is the uneven nature of the distress right now. This is NOT a liquidity crisis. Lodging is hurting badly, retail and office less so. But other types of commercial real estate, such as warehousing and industrial, are not hurting at all. Additionally, there's so much extra capital/liquidity floating around right now that investors are anxious to either purchase properties outright from delinquent owners, or to refinance or otherwise shore up/profit from the distressed owners. Furthermore, banks (themselves flush with liquidity) are also willing to negotiate with mortgagees, knowing that some sort of payment is better than no payment (witness last year's Mall of America massive renegotiation). All of this collectively is keeping loan delinquencies low. The excess liquidity and lopsided real estate "pain" make this a very unusual "recession." All of these factors lead me to believe that even with the "main street" economy worsening, this rate is highly likely to stay below 2% this quarter.
Reference website: FRED graphs/data at link above.

With COVID the rate has increased by about 0.2% each quarter from 0.68% in 2019 Q4 to 1.16% in Q4, 2020.  The rate was fairly steady over all of 2020.  While the economy has taken a beating, the chance that this rate will increase is low now that the vaccine is out and people will be able to beginning going back to commerical businesses at an increasing rate over the next 4 months.  If we assume the rate continues however we would expect the Q1, 21 to end with a rate of 1.36% and the end of Q2, 21 to end with a rate of 1.56%.  The rate would have to more then double to hit more then 2%.  While that is possible that sort of progress doesnt seem likely after the vaccine is out, quarteen patterns are becoming less stringent....   The most rapid increase was seen in 2008, during the house bubble bursting.  That was a rate of about 1% increase each quarter.  So it is possible, but i find it unlikely that businesses will do worse with quarenteen decreasing.

In the worst of the 2008 recession, the default rate was 8.75%. Back in '91 it was 11.91%. In Q4 2020 we were starting to see it trend upward but still very low, at 1.16%. This article (https://www.nationalmortgagenews.com/opinion/commercial-real-estate-loan-defaults-where-do-we-go-from-here) notes that "Retail, office, hospitality and small- business loans" are the most at risk for default, but also that the defaults are going to speed up in 2021. This article (https://www.mba.org/2021-press-releases/january/commercial-and-multifamily-mortgage-delinquencies-rise-in-december) indicates the situation was worse in January than it was in December. But the difference between 1.16 and 2.00 is a 72% increase, which I think is unlikely. As we start to see the US economy recover from COVID, I think the chances are low that we'll see the rate tick up above 2.00%, but I'm going to hedge by putting the chances of 2.00-4.00 at 35%.
The banking system is so incenstuous and overleveraged that these loans will not be allowed to default. They will make arrangements and defer payments.

The work from home movement seems to be a lasting trend that will survive beyond the pandemic. At this point unemployment is still very high. I believe the economy was already heading for a recession and the pandemic has simply uncovered problems that were already in existence. What matters is the size of the bubble, not the size of the pin; the pandemic was the pin. There are lasting problems for the commercial real estate market that will not be solved by fixing covid. Inflation is rising; I believe it will be at least 3% going forward. Inflation is ultimately what is going to destroy this economy. The only tool government has to combat this is printing more money and handing it out, which will only accelerate the inflation.  There's a continued trend of people moving out of the big cities to more rural areas, partially because of work from home, and partially because of a desire to flee the continued political unrest. Also, many amenities that used to be in place for city living are no longer available. I think things are very bad for the commercial real estate market long-term. Over 100,000 restaurants have gone out of business. 61% of restaurants and 35% of small businesses could not pay their rent in December.  However, there are some things that have been implemented that will push out the damage until later. I think this is very bad policy for the economy, because it is simply encouraging unprofitable businesses to stay in place. For purposes of this question though it means that default rates won't jump as quickly as they otherwise would. These new policies include PPP loans (which are really grants) to businesses and a restructuring of the bankruptcy market which allows tenants to be in place for an additional 90 days longer than the otherwise would be. I don't think the historical trends tell us very much. What is going on now is unprecedented. Much worse than 2008 ultimately. I think that despite the PPP loans and bankruptcy restructuring there will be many business owners that will opt to simply cash in their chips because they see the writing on the wall for their business. https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/commercial-real-estate-bankruptcy-legislation-introduced https://www.zerohedge.com/personal-finance/work-home-threatens-commercial-real-estate-valuations https://www.zerohedge.com/personal-finance/us-has-lost-more-110000-restaurants-setting-stage-commercial-real-estate-collapse https://cms.zerohedge.com/economics/record-61-restaurants-35-small-businesses-cant-pay-december-rent?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+zerohedge%2Ffeed+%28zero+hedge+-+on+a+long+enough+timeline%2C+the+survival+rate+for+everyone+drops+to+zero%29

Looking at CMBS pricing as a proxy for CRE risk: CMBS ETF is up 5% YTD, compared with 10% for similar duration treasuries. So the spread component (extra yield above treasuries) is out 5%. Assume that half of that is a risk premium, and half of that is due to default risk. So 2.5% is due to default risk, and if you assume a recovery rate of 50% that means a 5% default cycle over the life of the CMBS. The big question is how much you get and when.

While continued rise in CMBS delinquency seems unescapable, the issue is timing: lenders forbearance, US government stimulus delays the peak of delinquencies. 
So far given the magnitude of the crisis, delinquency rate increase is small: 1.00 in Q3 vs. 0.92 in Q2. We have three quarter before the end of this question. 
The increase in delinquency rates is very likely to be non-linear, so I not counting on continued 10bps increase over the next 3 qtr.
I’m shocked the forecasts haven’t moved more in light of the positive vaccine news.

Current: According to the Mortgage Bankers Association's latest monthly MBA CREF Loan Performance Survey, U.S. delinquency rates for mortgages backed by commercial and multifamily properties declined in September 2020. "Commercial and multifamily mortgage performance has stabilized, and in many cases, has begun to slowly improve since the initial stress of April and May," said Jamie Woodwell, MBA's Vice President of Commercial Real Estate Research. "Lodging and retail properties felt the onset of the recession most immediately and dramatically, and that continues to show in the numbers. Delinquency rates remain more muted among other property types and overall, the inflow of newly delinquent loans has slowed to one-fourth the rate seen in April." Key U.S. Commercial Loan Performance Survey for September 2020:   The share of commercial and multifamily loan balances that were current increased in September, rising to 94.3% from 93.6% in August, with fewer new loans becoming delinquent. World Property Journal  US Commercial Mortgage Delinquencies in U.S. Dip in September The share of loans that are 90+ days delinquent rose slightly: from 2.9% to 3.0%.
The share of loans that are 60-90 days delinquent held steady at 0.6%.
The share of loans that are 30-60 days delinquent fell from 0.8% to 0.7%.
The share of loans less than 30 days delinquent fell from 1.6% to 0.9%. Next year:  Banks (any source of lending) will be looking to recover losses from this year.  Their balances sheets will be carrying significant debt and bad loans, similar to 2018.  They'll stop lending to all but the ones who already have money.  Credit tightens significantly.  Most available source becomes the FED, and particularly Freddy and his siblings.  start dumping real estate to improve their balance sheets.

"According to Trepp data procured by NAI Global, delinquency rates on CMBS-based loans spiked in May of this year to 7.16 percent of total outstanding loans, from 2.33 percent in April.
In June, the CMBS delinquency rate on loans backed by these securities jumped to 10.32 percent, which is a 748 basis point rise from one year ago when the delinquency rate was 2.84 percent.

While my bias is that the economy is about to get hit hard, especially the commercial real estate market, I'm going to try to actually follow forecasting procedures here and start with the historic record.  I know generals are always trying to fight the last war and are never really ready for the current war. This recession is not going to be like the last one. The last recession started in the residential market and then leaked over into the commercial market, this one will start more in the commercial market. Even so, looking at what happened in the 2008 crisis, in the initial one-year period delinquencies only increased 1.4%. Even during the steepest increase it only increased by 3.9% in a 12 month period. So historically I wouldn't expect it to be above 5% by Q2 2021. The biggest wild card to me is government intervention. The government could issue more decrees that renters are able to stay and not be evicted. This could really hurt mortgage holders.

Interesting article that shows what it would take to reach a delinquency rate of 8%. https://www.globest.com/2020/04/01/cre-loan-defaults-soar-under-trepp-stress-test-but-wont-be-as-bad-as-great-recession/
https://info.trepp.com/hubfs/Trepp%20CRE%20Loan%20Defaults%20and%20Loss%20Report%20_%20July%202020-2.pdf To achieve a 8% delinquency rate a stress test required:
1) GDP falls precipitously (drops of 35% to 40%)
2) unemployment rate rises (The unemployment rate starts at 18% in Q2 2020, then declines, reaching 13% by early 2021.)
3) interest rates remain low.
4) asset prices fall (as much as 40% decline in some industries)
https://www.globest.com/2020/04/01/cre-loan-defaults-soar-under-trepp-stress-test-but-wont-be-as-bad-as-great-recession/ The four criteria have not materialized:
1) Fitch's September estimate is a contraction of -4.6% for US GDP. 
2) unemployment seems to have rebounded in part and now recovering at a slower pace. We are already better than the 13%-18% used in the modest.
3) Interests remain do remain low and the Federal Reserve has signal such a policy which will likely help commercial real estate more than it hurts.
4) Commercial real estate prices have remained stable per the St. Louis FRED platform, no price decline yet that is comparable to the great recession. https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/COMREPUSQ159N

The current projections look relatively good to me, and I don't see anything that makes me think it will be higher than 4% right now. Slight concern with COVID resurgence or strong economic hit due to a variety of reasons though.

There are two other related resources that may provide (historical) comparison: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/release/tables?rid=231&eid=148470&od
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DRALACBS Our topic - "Delinquency Rate on Commercial Real Estate Loans (Excluding Farmland), Booked in Domestic Offices, All Commercial Banks (DRCRELEXFACBS)" - depends largely on the economic cycle and is more volatile than the more general loan delinquency: in boom times, the rate in the commercial real estate loans comes down much further than other sectors, depending probably on the long-term growth outlook and the sustainability of the boom, which influences long-term investment decision and businesses' commitment to expansion. The recent boom ended abruptly, and more so than the boom before the "Great Recession", and the recent boom appears to have been even "healthier" before the pandemic than in 2006: the current low was 0.67% (Q2 2019), the low point in Q2 2006 was at 1.02%. 
Projecting forward, we will have to predict the rate four quarters from now, since the latest of the quarterly figures is "as of 30 June 2020/Q2 2020", so there will be four more publications until resolution: Q3, Q4 2020 plus Q1, Q2 2021, of which Q3 2020 is due to be published probably in October 2020. From the overview table one can see that the commercial real estate loan business in general has the lowest delinquency rates of all, which may correlate to the larger sums in the game and the intense risk assessment on the one hand, and on the other hand more professional approach of commercial debtors and businesses being better equipped with equity and cash than any other sector. However, after the boom ends, the (DRCRELEXFACBS) rate tends to rise much faster than other sectors, which can be observed already in the four quarters Q2 2019 to Q2 2020: Q2 2019: 0.67%
Q2 2020: 0.92% (+37.31%)
of which the quarters
Q1 2020 (the third quarter after cyclical low; +22.1% quarter over quarter) and 
Q2 2020 (the fourth quarter after cyclical low; +10.8% quarter over quarter)
saw the fastest pace.
It is a bit surprising that the increase of delinquency rates has already begun for real *before* the pandemic actually began, so in my reading even without SARS-CoV-2 the US economy has likely been in the beginning of a cyclical recession. For comparison All Loans (DRALACBS):
Q2 2019: 1.49%
Q2 2020: 1.54% (+3.36%) For the purpose of a projection, one can try to replicate the growth of delinquency of the quarters Q3 2007 to Q2 2008, if one assumed the evolution of the crisis will be equivalent. However, as the pandemic came as a surprise and an "external economic shock" and the federal subsidies for cash-strapped businesses and interventions by the Federal Reserve System are, in my opinion, much bigger and more significant in 2020 than it was the case in Q3 2007 to Q2 2008, so it is likely the dispersion of growth rates quarter over quarter will be different: the highest impact was right at the beginning in Q1 2020, and after the loan market had time to adapt to the shock, growth rates are expected to be slightly lower than in the historic precedent. Under these assumtions, I get to the following projection: The historic precedent:
Q4 2006: 1.32%
Q1 2007: 1.43% (+8.33%)
Q2 2007: 1.63% (+13.99%)
Q3 2007: 1.97% (+ 20.86%)
Q4 2007: 2.75% (+39.60%)
Q1 2008: 3.50% (+27.27%)
Q2 2008: 4.16% (+18.86%) Projection until Q2 2021:
Q4 2019: 0.68
Q1 2020: 0.83% (+22.06%)
Q2 2020: 0.92% (+10.84%)
Q3 2020: 1.086%est. (+18.0%est.)
Q4 2020: 1.487%est. (+37.0%est.)
Q1 2021: 1.859%est. (+25.0%est.)
Q2 2021: 2.175%est. (+17.0%est.) I would consider this the best case scenario, since it includes the assumption that deliquencies will be able to adjourned until a vaccine is in place and widely available, so the pandemic conditions are basically over before the vast limitations for businesses can cause major persistent damage on the commercial real estate loan market. However, I rule out that - even under the most advantageous conditions - the delinquency rate will remain below 2.00% and thus I rule out bin 1. However, considering the "big picture", there is an alternative projection method and a different solution, which will serve as the normal case scenario henceforth.
If you compare commercial real estate loans with all loans (DRALACBS) historically, they have an intersection pretty much at the beginning of the underlying recession, which means that (DRCRELEXFACBS) not only catches up but lies higher than the all loans in the recession, which started statistically in Q1 2020 if I remember correctly. This means the pandemic effect would exacerbate the delinquency rate in commercial real estate segment to unprecedented growth rates of maybe 50% to 100% qoq in Q3 2020, caused maybe by consumer behavior, limitations to consumer lending and thus spending, higher unemployment and less disposable income and so forth. The publication of the next figures per Q3 2020 will give more insight over the path ahead!
In figures, this would mean:
Q2 2020: 0.92%
Q3 2020 est. (+50%): 1.38%
Q3 2020 est. (+100%): 1.84% For comparison, All loans (DRALACBS) figure:
Q2 2020: 1.54%
Q3 2020 est. (+10%): 1.694% This would constitute a totally different growth path, at the end of which over four quarters a rate in the high 4% or 5% can not be excluded - and which is why GJO likely asked exactly this question exactly now. A mark-up will be used to reflect this effect to retrieve the worst case scenario further below. As per historical precedent, delinquencies in commercial real estate loans (DRCRELEXFACBS) grew
Q2 2006: 1.02%
Q2 2008: 4.16% (+307.8%) Q2 2019:  0.67%
Q2 2021 est. (+307.8%): 2.73% (normal case scenario, which is still 34,4% below the value of the "Great Recession", at 4.16%) As a markup to the pandemic effect, I choose to take the average of Q2 2019 of All loans and commercial real estate loans, which lies at 1.08% ((0.67%+1.49%)/2) (Q2 2019*) to correct for the fact that one third up to half of the businesses' investment decision would certainly not have been made between Q2 2019 and Q4 2019, if decision makers had known that there would be pandemic in 2020 and a complete lock down in many places in the US in Q2 2020. Thus, with the imaginary starting point of 1.08% in Q2 2019 and the real growth rate retrieved from historic precedent, I receive my worst case scenario for the time being (which could definitely become worse, depending on Q3 2020 figures published): Q2 2019*:1.08%
Q2 2021* est. (+307.8%): 4.40% My forecast reflects that the best case and the normal case lie on bin 2 pretty far off of the threshold to the upper side, but also that the worst case already lies on bin 3, and that there's a significant risk the "worst case" could be topped by reality.
My conclusion is that the commercial real estate loans sector will observe fast rising delinquency rates (DRCRELEXFACBS) over the next four quarters and delinquencies will rise much faster than for the average "all loans" segment (DRALACBS). My scenarios are
/2.175% (best case; 10% weight)
/2.733% (normal case; 10% weight)
/4.405% (worst case; 80% weight)
which is why I my weighted average forecast of 4.015% is right on the threshold between bin 2 and bin 3, at least until the figures for Q3 2020 are published. Delinquency rates of 6.00% or higher are very likely in this business cycle, but from my point of view they are not going to be observed before Q4 2021 for the commercial real estate loan market.

I'm prepared to be very wrong on this one... but let's just look at the current data. Current rates are really low.. in the 0.7% range. That's lower than the 2000s recession and much lower than 2010. So lots of room to grow. Only numbers out right now are Q2 2020 numbers when the CARES act was in affect so Q3 2020 will be important to watch. Let's pretend like it's 2008 and say we're at the beginning of that curve up (Q2 2007). After 4 quarters, the delinquency rate had only raised by 2.5%. If you go for a more aggressive version of this and say we start right at the beginning of the recession (Q1 2008), then even that rate of increase is only a 3% increase over 4 quarters. What could make this worse than 2008? Certainly that there might be a lot of pent up loan delinquencies coming. On the other hand, there could be a lot of desire to keep tenants. Companies that own/loan commercial real estate certainly understand the shift to online shopping, working from home, online services. Can't imagine they're super thrilled about the idea of killing their revenue stream only to have no way to fill it. Might be against the grain, but based on all that. The high end of 2008 says we could raise as high as 4%. To start, I'm considering a normal distribution, centered close to that 4% mark and will refine from there.

@Leonardthethird explanation sounds very well structured, so I'll just follow  that, but will carve out "less than 2%" in favor of "between  2 and 4%"

Outside-ish View - PPP money is gone, no add'l major stimulus in sight at the moment (though I think likely to be passed within this timeframe such that it materially affects the outcome). Gut is to weight mid-high bins most heavily. Poking around a bit, the huge delta between commercial bank and CMBS loan spikes in Q2 is really striking. [1] It may be worth noting here that in the Great Recession, CMBS delinquencies tracked roughly about 450 bps higher than commercial loans. With CMBS nearing 10% in 2Q2020, if the same relationship were to follow here, that would support, in my estimation, weighting bins 3-5 heavily, with the fattest part of the curve in bin 4 or 5. Inside View - This is my industry, and my anecdotal/small sample size experience is that banks really don't want to be taking back properties right now, and are thus executing forebearance agreements (typically allowing for interest-only payments in three-month increments) left and right, thus mitigating the number of loans that become delinquent in the first place. I'm mostly ignoring this inside view for the moment... [1] https://www.mba.org/news-research-and-resources/research-and-economics/commercial/-multifamily-research/commercial/multifamily-mortgage-delinquency-rates
